Appendix 3, page 3

A.

Economic Analysis

7. 
The  economic  viability  of  the  five  core  subprojects  selected  were  analyzed  as  a
basis  for  preparing  the  Project.  Economic  analysis  determined  the  incremental  benefits  and

costs  accruing  from  the  subproject  implementation.

1.

Benefits

The Project will benefit the economy at large by providing a pool of technicians and
8. 
professionals with appropriate knowledge to make useful contribution to economic recovery
and long-term sustainable industrial, commercial, and agricultural growth of  Indonesia. The
Project  is  designed  to  make the  higher education institutions more  responsive  to  labor
market needs.  The Project will also benefit graduates of  the participating institutions who,
by receiving better quality and more relevant education in priority programs, should be able
to  find  suitable  initial  employment  upon  graduation  and  secure  continued  career
development. The  staff  development activity of the  Project will  benefit teachers of  higher
technological
education  institutions  by  improving  their  skills  to  keep  pace  with 
developments. Enterprises and other employers will benefit from the availability of a better
trained pool of skilled technicians and professionals, facilitating improved production quality,
increased productivity, and more efficient management. In addition, the  Project will result in
more cost-effective use of public and private financing of higher education.

9. 
Most  of  the  benefits are  difficult to  quantify. There  is  no  standard  procedure  to
quantify  benefits  in  education projects and  no estimates of  the  positive externalities from
public  investment  in  higher  education  are  available.  A  difference  in  earnings  of  the
graduates  is  considered an  appropriate measure of the  social benefits of  the  investment.
The  Project is  expected to  lead to  higher lifetime earnings of  the  graduates of the  project
institutions by:

(i) 
(ii) 
(iii) 

reducing the time needed for students to graduate from 5.75 to 5.00 years
reducing the time the graduates take to find their first job, and
increasing starting salaries of graduates once employed.

11.  Reduces Waiting Time.  The Project would reduce the time graduates take before
they get their first job  through (i) improving in the quality of  the  priority programs, (ii)
